newsitem.title: USA: U.S. suspends patrol flights over Zaire. [CORRECTED 23:55 GMT]
newsitem.headline: U.S. suspends patrol flights over Zaire. [CORRECTED 23:55 GMT]

text.p: The United States on Thursday suspended flights of military reconnaissance planes over Zaire after one of the unarmed aircraft apparently came under anti-aircraft fire on Wednesday, the Pentagon said.

"There are no reconnaissance flights today. We are reassessing the flights in the light of the incidents yesterday," Defence Department spokesman Ken Bacon told reporters. The P-3 Orion (corrects from P-5 Orion) patrol plane based in Uganda was not hit in Wednesday's incident and Bacon said he expected the flights to resume.
Bacon said the plane was flying at 19,000 feet (6,300 metres) and was several thousand feet above what the crew believed to be eight air bursts of anti-aircraft shells as it flew south of Goma.
It was one of two four-engine Navy P-3 submarine hunter aircraft which are helping search for refugees in Zaire.
"I would expect the flights to be resumed, but I don't know when," Bacon said, adding that the planes might fly even higher in the future to avoid possible anti-aircraft fire.
It was not known what type of guns were used or who fired at the plane, Bacon said.
